Question: Consider the following logical statement: ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S).
Show, using logical equivalences, that this statement is logically equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
You may use the following logical equivalences: Material Implication: P → Q ≡ ~P ∨ Q; De Morgan's Laws: ~(P ∧ Q) ≡ ~P ∨ ~Q and ~(P ∨ Q) ≡ ~P ∧ ~Q; Double Negation: ~(~P) ≡ P.

Solution: 
<think>
Alright, so I need to show that the statement ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S) is logically equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Hmm, okay.
Let me think about how to approach this.
First, I remember that material implication is one of the tools I can use here.
The material implication formula says that P → Q is equivalent to ~P ∨ Q.
So maybe I can apply that to the original statement.
The original statement is ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S).
Using material implication, that should be equivalent to ~[~ (P ∧ Q)] ∨ (R ∨ S).
Wait, no, hold on.
Material implication is P → Q ≡ ~P ∨ Q.
So in this case, P is ~ (P ∧ Q), and Q is (R ∨ S).
So it's ~ [~ (P ∧ Q)] ∨ (R ∨ S).
But the double negation says ~ ( ~P ) is P, so ~ [~ (P ∧ Q)] is just P ∧ Q.
So that simplifies to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Wait, is that it? So ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S) simplifies directly to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S) using material implication and double negation? Let me double-check that.
Starting with ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S).
Applying material implication: ~ (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Then, using De Morgan's Law on ~ (P ∧ Q), that becomes ~P ∨ ~Q.
So the expression becomes (~P ∨ ~Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Now, using the distributive law of OR over OR, which I think is another logical equivalence, so (~P ∨ ~Q) ∨ (R ∨ S) becomes (~P ∨ R) ∨ (~Q ∨ S).
But I'm not sure if that helps.
Alternatively, maybe I can look for another way.
Wait, earlier I thought that ~[~ (P ∧ Q)] is P ∧ Q, so maybe I can write it as (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
But is that accurate? Let me make sure.
Yes, because the material implication ~(A) → B is equivalent to A ∨ B.
So in this case, A is (P ∧ Q), so ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S) is (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
So that's the equivalence.
I think that's correct.
So the original statement is equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S) using material implication and De Morgan's Law.

</think>

The original statement is ~(P ∧ Q) → (R ∨ S).
Using material implication, this becomes ~ (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Applying De Morgan's Law, ~ (P ∧ Q) is ~P ∨ ~Q.
So the expression becomes (~P ∨ ~Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Using the distributive property, this is equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
Therefore, the statement is logically equivalent to (P ∧ Q) ∨ (R ∨ S).
